newsitem.title: USA: North Dakota rains replenish soil moisture levels.
newsitem.headline: North Dakota rains replenish soil moisture levels.

text.p: Much-needed rains helped replenish North Dakota's soil moisture levels during the week ended Sunday, the state's agricultural statistics service said in its weekly crop progress report.
Although the rains halted harvest activity, they were expected to help edible bean knifing and potato digging.
Statewide topsoil moisture rating increased considerable from the previous week and were near last year and above the five-year average.
Blackbirds were still a problem in some sunflower fields and grasshoppers remained a problem in the southwest.
DNS wheat combined 95 percent vs 92 year ago, 87 average.
Durum wheat combined 81 percent vs 78 y/a, 75 avge.
Oats combined 98 percent vs 93 y/a, 94 avge.
Barley combined 99 percent vs 98 y/a, 95 avge.
Sunflower bracts turned yellow 94 pct vs 91 y/a, 83 avge.
Potatoes dug 36 percent vs 47 year ago, 52 avge.
Topsoil moisture rated 4 percent surplus, 72 adequate, 22 short and 2 very short, versus average of four surplus, 63 adequate, 28 short and five very short.
